metadata.name: Educational Dysfunctions
metadata.description: Patterns that undermine learning effectiveness, engagement, or wellbeing. Critical for AI tutoring systems to detect and avoid. Covers lecture overload, teaching to the test, one-size-fits-all, grade inflation, punitive feedback, learned helplessness, cognitive overload, surface learning, disengaged teaching, rigid pacing, extrinsic dependence, and fear-based motivation.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Patterns that undermine learning effectiveness, engagement, or wellbeing

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Educational dysfunctions often harm learner autonomy and wellbeing

positive_examples: The class was just endless lecturing with no engagement.
They only teach what's on the standardized test.
Students are shamed when they give wrong answers.
Rote memorization without any deeper understanding.
negative_examples: Students explored the topic through hands-on activities.
The teacher provided individualized support.
Learning was connected to real-world applications.
training_hints.disambiguation: Harmful teaching patterns, not effective practices

candidates.definition: Excessive passive information delivery without active engagement or application

positive_examples: The professor talked for 90 minutes straight while we just sat there.
Death by PowerPoint - slide after slide with no interaction.
Students are passive recipients of information, never getting to apply or discuss.
Three-hour lectures with no breaks, discussions, or activities.
negative_examples: The instructor paused regularly for questions and discussion.
Every 15 minutes we did a think-pair-share activity.
The flipped classroom model reserved class time for active learning.
training_hints.disambiguation: Excessive passive lecturing, not any lecture use

candidates.definition: Narrowing instruction to test content at expense of deeper understanding and broader skills

positive_examples: We only cover what's on the state test - no time for anything else.
Forget critical thinking - just memorize these answers.
The curriculum has been reduced to test prep.
Teachers are pressured to focus only on tested material.
negative_examples: We pursue interesting tangents even if they're not on the test.
Deeper understanding matters more than test scores.
The curriculum includes enrichment beyond what's assessed.
training_hints.disambiguation: Narrowing to test content, not all test preparation

candidates.definition: Ignoring individual differences in pace, style, background, and needs

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: One-size-fits-all ignores learner individuality and needs

positive_examples: Everyone does the same work at the same pace regardless of ability.
No accommodations for different learning needs.
The lesson ignores students' varying backgrounds and prior knowledge.
Lockstep instruction that leaves some behind and bores others.
negative_examples: Students worked at their own pace on personalized learning paths.
The teacher provided multiple options for demonstrating learning.
Instruction was adapted based on individual student needs.
training_hints.disambiguation: Ignoring individual differences, not having standards

candidates.definition: Awarding higher grades than performance warrants, undermining feedback and standards

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Grade inflation provides misleading feedback about performance

positive_examples: Everyone gets an A regardless of effort or quality.
Standards have dropped so low that passing is guaranteed.
Grades no longer distinguish between excellent and mediocre work.
The average GPA has risen while learning has declined.
negative_examples: Grades accurately reflect the quality of work.
High standards are maintained consistently.
Feedback distinguishes between levels of performance.
training_hints.disambiguation: Unwarranted high grades, not generous but fair grading

candidates.definition: Feedback focused on criticism and punishment rather than growth and improvement

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Punitive feedback can harm learner wellbeing and autonomy

positive_examples: The teacher's red pen slashed through errors with no explanation.
Public humiliation for wrong answers.
You should be ashamed of this work.
Grades used as weapons rather than tools for growth.
negative_examples: Here's specifically what to do to improve.
Mistakes are learning opportunities.
Private, constructive feedback focused on next steps.
training_hints.disambiguation: Punishing errors rather than using them for learning

candidates.definition: Pattern where repeated failure leads learners to believe they cannot succeed

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Learned helplessness represents collapse of learner agency

positive_examples: I'm just bad at math - there's no point in trying.
After failing so many times, she stopped even attempting the problems.
Why bother studying? I'll just fail anyway.
Repeated failure without support leads to giving up.
negative_examples: Even though it's hard, I know I can improve with practice.
That didn't work - let me try a different approach.
Struggle is part of learning, not a sign that I can't do it.
training_hints.disambiguation: Giving up due to repeated failure, not temporary frustration

candidates.definition: Presenting too much information at once, exceeding working memory capacity

positive_examples: Too much information at once - I can't process it all.
The lesson tried to cover five new concepts in one session.
Complex diagrams with dense text and no scaffolding.
Working memory completely overwhelmed by extraneous demands.
negative_examples: Material was broken into manageable chunks.
New concepts were introduced gradually.
Scaffolding reduced processing demands.
training_hints.disambiguation: Too much at once, not challenging material

candidates.definition: Memorization and reproduction without understanding or ability to transfer

positive_examples: Students memorized the formula but couldn't explain when to use it.
He can recite the definition but doesn't understand what it means.
Cramming for the test, then forgetting everything the next day.
Rote learning without any meaningful engagement with ideas.
negative_examples: She can apply the concept to novel situations.
Deep understanding that transfers to new contexts.
Students can explain the why, not just the what.
training_hints.disambiguation: Memorization without understanding, not memory use generally

candidates.definition: Going through motions without genuine investment in learner success

positive_examples: The teacher clearly didn't care whether students understood.
Just covering the material without checking comprehension.
Reading from slides with no passion or interaction.
Going through the motions without genuine investment.
negative_examples: The teacher was clearly passionate about the subject.
She adjusted her approach when students were confused.
He genuinely cared about each student's progress.
training_hints.disambiguation: Lack of genuine care, not introversion or quiet style

candidates.definition: Forcing all learners through content at same pace regardless of mastery

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Rigid pacing ignores individual learner needs

positive_examples: Everyone moves on Monday regardless of whether they've mastered it.
The schedule determines pace, not student learning.
No time for remediation - we have to stay on track.
Some students left behind, others bored waiting.
negative_examples: Students advance when they demonstrate mastery.
Flexible pacing allows for individual needs.
Those who need more time get it.

candidates.definition: Over-reliance on external rewards and punishments that undermine intrinsic motivation

positive_examples: Will this be on the test? If not, I'm not learning it.
I only study for the sticker or prize.
Once rewards stop, so does the behavior.
External motivation has crowded out genuine interest.
negative_examples: I'm curious about this topic for its own sake.
Learning is its own reward.
I want to master this skill for personal satisfaction.
training_hints.disambiguation: Excessive reliance on external motivation, not any use of rewards

candidates.definition: Using anxiety, shame, or threat as primary motivators, damaging learning and wellbeing

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Fear-based motivation uses coercion and harms wellbeing

positive_examples: If you fail this test, you'll never get into college.
I'm terrified of making mistakes in this class.
The teacher uses shame and public humiliation as motivators.
Learning driven by fear of consequences rather than genuine interest.
negative_examples: It's safe to make mistakes here - that's how we learn.
I'm motivated by curiosity and genuine interest.
The classroom feels psychologically safe.
training_hints.disambiguation: Fear as primary motivator, not appropriate concern about consequences
